{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3113318,"name":"EricRehder","username":"EricRehder","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/7ab992/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-12-23T14:35:38.492Z","cooked":"

I’m looking to get the team committed to crimping with inspection to really boost our electrical connection quality this year. But I’m unsure how to inspect a crimp and what P/F guidelines are. Any advice? This would be for battery lines on 6AWG, motor lines on 10AWG, and CAN lines.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-12-23T14:35:38.492Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1183,"reads":292,"readers_count":291,"score":5988.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":420123,"topic_slug":"crimp-inspection","display_username":"EricRehder","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/can-problems/420438/12","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Can Problems","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32451,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/crimp-inspection/420123/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3113324,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-23T15:25:33.830Z","cooked":"

Visual:

  • Is there stripped wire where its supposed to be (in the crimped area with a tiny bit on each end, if its visible)
  • Is there rubber where its supposed to be (in the jacket crimp if there is one, and NOT in the wire crimping zone, and not leaving a big gap between the crimp assembly and the jacket.
    Pull test:
    REV advocates a sensible pull. For tiny stuff (CAN and PWM), its a gentle tug. If it comes off, you needed to try again anyway. For 10 and 12 AWG, pull hard, but DON’T pull on the tails! IE, hold the WIRE and the crimp. For battery cable, pull as hard as you can! It should hold your entire body weight. Honestly, #10 and #12 should too, but its harder to get a grip on them without messing something up…
","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-12-23T15:25:33.830Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":275,"readers_count":274,"score":110.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":420123,"topic_slug":"crimp-inspection","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"/tag/10","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"/tag/12","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/crimp-inspection/420123/2","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3113328,"name":"Tom","username":"Zook","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zook/{size}/252720_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-23T15:35:03.861Z","cooked":"

Every wire gauge has a minimum force required to make a proper crimp.
Every connector has a specially shaped tool for crimping it.

Always buy the correct tool type with the correct force capability for the crimp connections and wire gauge combination you are using. It is far better to have 5 different tools (properly labeled!!!), each doing a near perfect job for a small range of connections than trying to force the issue with a wrong tool.

For large wire, 6 or even 4 gauge, the wiggle test is important. You may not be able to pull the wire out of the crimp, but if you can make it rotate/wiggle a little side to side, you need to replace it.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-12-23T15:35:50.924Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":248,"readers_count":247,"score":94.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":420123,"topic_slug":"crimp-inspection","display_username":"Tom","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14980,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4276 nice mentor"},"post_url":"/t/crimp-inspection/420123/3","custom_user_title":"4276 nice mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3113365,"name":"EricRehder","username":"EricRehder","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/7ab992/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-12-23T18:00:10.585Z","cooked":"

I’m expecting two or three forms of inspection. First is inspection done during training/certification of a member. This may involve cutting it open and inspecting where more time is available. Second may be a checkout at the start of a work session where test samples are made and can be destructively tested. Then there are real operating crimps that go on the robot.
Are you doing pull tests on real operating crimps? That would identify bad ones but seems like it could hurt good crimps as well.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-12-23T18:00:10.585Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":184,"readers_count":183,"score":66.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":420123,"topic_slug":"crimp-inspection","display_username":"EricRehder","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32451,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/crimp-inspection/420123/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3113366,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-23T18:04:13.975Z","cooked":"
EricRehder:

Are you doing pull tests on real operating crimps?

Yes.

If a bad crimp makes it onto the robot, it’s BAD.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-12-23T18:04:13.975Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":168,"readers_count":167,"score":53.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":420123,"topic_slug":"crimp-inspection","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/crimp-inspection/420123/5","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3113389,"name":"Troy Dietz","username":"troy_dietz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/troy_dietz/{size}/135768_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-23T19:21:22.622Z","cooked":"
Zook:

It is far better to have 5 different tools (properly labeled!!!), each doing a near perfect job for a small range of connections than trying to force the issue with a wrong tool.

You mean that crimping our battery lugs and 14awg ring terminals all in the same bench vise is wrong?

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-12-23T19:21:22.622Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":147,"readers_count":146,"score":64.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":420123,"topic_slug":"crimp-inspection","display_username":"Troy Dietz","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"❤️ conflict-free COTS"},"post_url":"/t/crimp-inspection/420123/6","custom_user_title":"❤️ conflict-free COTS","reactions":[{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3113562,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-24T14:40:38.052Z","cooked":"
Zook:

correct tool type with the correct force capability

and beware that the correct tool squeezed too hard can bend the terminal to a banana shape which is bad.

Inspect with a magnifying glass. Light can help, too, for some of us old folks.

Also, separate conductors of multi-wire cables from each other and keep them separate in the shells and tied down beyond the minimum distance back from the crimp. This is important so the terminals float well in the shells.

Manufacturers provide specs in the minimum distances for the separation but finding that information is a challenging treasure hunt. Here’s an example from Molex PRODUCT SPEC MINI-FIT JR. (12 pages long and about 12 pages more than any student cares to read.)

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-12-24T14:40:38.052Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":112,"readers_count":111,"score":57.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":420123,"topic_slug":"crimp-inspection","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.molex.com/pdm_docs/ps/PS-5556-001.pdf","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":15}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/crimp-inspection/420123/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3113571,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-12-24T15:26:31.367Z","cooked":"

As others have already stated, use the proper (ratcheting) crimping tool for each size of wire.

I teach team members should do the appropriate pull test on each and every connection immediately after making each connection. I also teach that they should find another team member who is meticulous to check the connections afterwards. Iwill then do a final check. Typically, I will find a few loose connections that got past the two previous checks. This emulates the process used at places I have worked building electrical equipment for industrial applications except they would fire people who screwed up too many times.

The pull test should also be done on connections made using the Wago, Weidmuller and lever-nut connectors.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-12-24T15:26:31.367Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":97,"readers_count":96,"score":34.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":420123,"topic_slug":"crimp-inspection","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/crimp-inspection/420123/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3113607,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2022-12-24T18:00:49.509Z","cooked":"
EricRehder:

Are you doing pull tests on real operating crimps? That would identify bad ones but seems like it could hurt good crimps as well.

Echoing to confirm. I call it the 15 lbs tug test. If a crimp can’t survive that with flying colors, it shouldn’t be on the robot at all. It’ll break eventually.

It’s a simple and quick way to help push components past the "infant mortality " phase of the bathtub reliability curve.
